pages.exhaustive_description: A subscriber-only Business Insider feature on Brett Gibson’s path to venture capital. The piece states that, after graduating from the University of California, Santa Barbara with a B.A. in philosophy, Gibson was working in a pizza restaurant, taught himself to code from online articles, and obtained his first engineering job at Grand Central Communications in 2004. It then traces his formative start-up sequence—DrawHere (2005, sold to DeviantArt 2006); Slinkset (YC S 08); his merger into Posterous as co-founder in 2009; software work at Y Combinator rewriting its application/back-end systems; and finally his recruitment by Garry Tan to Initialized, where he built the firm’s internal “Folio” software before becoming a full-time investor. These passages supply the only publicly available details on his undergraduate degree and the self-directed, early-career experiences that shaped his trajectory.

mla_citation.page_title: Brett Gibson went from making pizza to a rising-star crypto VC at Initialized Capital. Here’s how a chance encounter with Garry Tan changed the course of his career.

pages.exhaustive_description: Speaker biography for “The Capital” (CoinMarketCap) conference. It identifies Gibson as a partner at Initialized and lists his entrepreneurial milestones—Posthaven, Posterous, Y Combinator software team, Slinkset (YC S 08) and DrawHere (2006 sale to DeviantArt). Crucially, it records: “Brett graduated with a B.A. in philosophy from the University of California, Santa Barbara,” corroborating his undergraduate education. No birth or family details appear.

mla_citation.page_title: Speaker: Brett Gibson | The Capital

pages.exhaustive_description: The Org’s public profile for Gibson (Managing Partner, Initialized). Under “Education” it lists “B.A. in Philosophy – UC Santa Barbara.” The work-history timeline shows pre-VC technical roles: software engineer at Grand Central Communications (2004-05); co-founder DrawHere (2005-06); developer at Sonific (2006-08); founder Slinkset (2008-09); co-founder Posterous (2009-10); Y Combinator software developer (2014-15); co-founder Posthaven (2013–). These entries illuminate his early, self-driven tech career immediately after college.

mla_citation.page_title: Brett Gibson – Managing Partner at Initialized Capital | The Org

pages.exhaustive_description: PitchBook’s investor profile preview. Education section states: “Graduated with a BA in philosophy from the University of California, Santa Barbara.” The bio restates his series of early companies (DrawHere, Slinkset, Posterous, Posthaven) and his software-engineering stint at Y Combinator prior to joining Initialized. These datapoints corroborate undergraduate credentials and outline formative entrepreneurial experience.

mla_citation.page_title: Brett Gibson Profile: Contact Information & Network | PitchBook

pages.exhaustive_description: Equilar ExecAtlas featured profile. Lists Education twice as “B.A., University of California, Santa Barbara.” The accompanying biography summarizes his pre-VC software career (DrawHere, Slinkset, Posterous, Posthaven, Y Combinator internal systems) and notes personal interest (“fond of pinball”). It confirms that his professional narrative before Initialized was entirely software-driven and that no graduate study is reported.

mla_citation.page_title: Brett Gibson – Executive Bio, Work History, and Contacts – Equilar ExecAtlas

pages.exhaustive_description: VC Sheet investor card. While it does not add schooling information, the page gives a concise chronology of Gibson’s early ventures—DrawHere (acquired 2006), Slinkset (YC 2008), Posterous (acquired by Twitter 2012), Posthaven (2013-), and his role building Y Combinator’s internal software—framing the formative technical experiences that preceded his move into venture capital.

mla_citation.page_title: Brett Gibson (Initialized Capital) / VC Breakdown & Contact

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch’s news post announces the public-beta launch of Posthaven, a paid blogging platform created by Posterous co-founders Garry Tan and Brett Gibson immediately after Twitter decided to shutter Posterous. The article identifies Gibson by name as a Posterous co-founder and Posthaven co-creator, explains Posthaven’s $5-per-month business model, states that Tan and Gibson ‘promised to keep the service running as long as it has users,’ and summarizes import figures (850,000 posts imported since February 15, 2013). It also quotes the founders on their long-term goal of data preservation and details road-map features they are personally building (post-by-email, multiple contributors, bookmarklet, etc.). Thus it establishes Gibson’s post-Posterous role as a software-building founder and operator outside of venture capital.

mla_citation.page_title: Posthaven Launches in Public Beta, Has Saved 850K Posts Since Posterous Announced Its Shutdown Date of April 30th

pages.exhaustive_description: The Verge’s feature about alternatives for users after Posterous’ closure devotes a large section to Posthaven. It notes that ‘Posterous co-founder Garry Tan … and another Posterous co-founder, Brett Gibson, decided to recreate the blogging platform when they heard Twitter planned to shut it down.’ The story calls Posthaven ‘Posterous redux,’ describes its ‘perfect importer,’ and quotes Tan saying ‘Both Brett and I have pledged to do this because we really believe that something like this should exist.’ The piece therefore documents Gibson’s status as a technical co-founder/operator of Posthaven and links him to Posterous’ earlier founding.

mla_citation.page_title: Posterous Is Shutting Down: Here Are the Best Alternatives

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch reports Posterous’ acquisition of fellow YC startup Slinkset. It states: ‘Slinkset.com will continue to operate, with Slinkset co-founder Brett Gibson joining Posterous full-time.’ The piece confirms that Gibson originally founded Slinkset (a white-label social-news platform) and that he transitioned into a senior engineering role at Posterous upon acquisition, illustrating his entrepreneurial and operator history before entering VC.

mla_citation.page_title: Posterous Acquires Fellow Y Combinator Alum Slinkset

pages.exhaustive_description: The Next Web covers the same acquisition one day later, emphasizing that ‘Slinkset founder Brett Gibson will also join the fellow YC startup as part of the acquisition.’ Additional background on Posterous’ growth provides third-party corroboration of Gibson’s founder status at Slinkset and his technical/operator move to Posterous.

mla_citation.page_title: Posterous Acquires Social News Site Creation Tool Slinkset

pages.exhaustive_description: Y Combinator’s official company profile for Posterous lists Brett Gibson as one of three founders (alongside Sachin Agarwal and Garry Tan). The page confirms the founding date (Summer 2008 YC batch), company description (‘Dead simple blogs by email’), status (acquired), location, and Gibson’s later bio line (“Managing Partner at Initialized Capital. Previously wrote software at YC, and founded YC cos Posterous, Posthaven, Slinkset”). This source authoritatively records Gibson’s co-founder role at Posterous, predating his VC career.

mla_citation.page_title: Posterous – Dead Simple Blogs by Email

pages.exhaustive_description: Y Combinator’s profile for Slinkset identifies Brett Gibson as a founder of the Summer 2008 startup and describes the product (‘white-label social news platform’) with status ‘Inactive.’ The entry independently substantiates Gibson’s founding of Slinkset and places it chronologically before his Posterous and Posthaven ventures.

mla_citation.page_title: Slinkset – Votable Lists

pages.exhaustive_description: Garry Tan’s Medium announcement of new hires at Initialized introduces ‘Brett Gibson … Operating Partner for Engineering.’ Tan recounts Gibson’s entire pre-VC résumé: co-founder of Posthaven and Posterous (acquired by Twitter); collaborator on Y Combinator’s internal software (interview, application, event, and alumni-network systems); founder of Slinkset; and co-founder of DrawHere, ‘a browser drawing startup acquired by DeviantArt in 2006.’ This firsthand narrative ties Gibson to each of his engineering/operator roles and explicitly confirms the DeviantArt exit, providing a consolidated, reliable timeline of his non-VC career.

mla_citation.page_title: Welcome Alda and Brett

pages.exhaustive_description: WebUrbanist’s art-tech roundup ‘Doing Graffiti Online’ includes a section headed ‘Draw Here’ with an in-line screenshot and link to DrawHere.com. It describes Draw Here as a browser bookmarklet that ‘lets you tag online while you’re visiting a web page’ and allows users to save and share their drawings. Although it does not name founders, the article documents the product’s existence, functionality, and timeframe (published 2009) and thereby supports Gibson’s claim—via other sources—of founding a browser-drawing startup that was later acquired by DeviantArt.

mla_citation.page_title: Doing Graffiti Online: 8 Generator & Creator Applications

pages.exhaustive_description: Spanish tech site Genbeta’s 2006 post ‘Drawhere, graffitea cualquier dirección web’ introduces DrawHere as a bookmarklet that lets users spray-paint graffiti over any webpage, adjust spray size and color, and save finished drawings with tags and RSS tracking. The publication date (13 Oct 2006) places DrawHere in the correct historical window for Gibson’s early startup, corroborating Medium’s later note that the company was acquired by DeviantArt the same year.

mla_citation.page_title: DrawHere, graffitea cualquier dirección web

pages.exhaustive_description: Business Insider’s profile traces Gibson’s entire road into venture capital.  It recounts his early engineering and founder years (Grand Central Communications 2004, DrawHere 2005-06, Slinkset 2008, Posterous 2009-12) and shows how Garry Tan persuaded him to join Initialized Capital in 2017 as its first Operating Partner for Engineering.  The story explains Gibson’s initial mandate to write “Folio,” the internal deal-flow and blind-voting software that the firm still uses daily, and how that role evolved into investing.  It records his promotion “last August” (August 2021) to General Partner and lists crypto-infrastructure deals he has led—Bison Trails, TRM Labs, Talos Trading—illustrating his thematic focus on crypto, dev-tools and infra.  The article provides first-person quotes on Initialized’s blind-voting philosophy and describes how Folio shapes the firm’s investment process, giving insight into Gibson’s product-driven, data-centric investment style.

mla_citation.page_title: “Brett Gibson went from making pizza to a rising-star crypto VC at Initialized Capital. Here’s how a chance encounter with Garry Tan changed the course of his career.”

pages.exhaustive_description: This Medium post by Initialized co-founder Garry Tan formally announces Brett Gibson’s entry into venture capital on 15 June 2017.  It states that Gibson is “joining us as Operating Partner for Engineering,” describes his responsibilities (advising portfolio companies on building world-class software teams and “build[ing] software that super-charges what we can do as a partnership”), and summarizes his technical founder background (Posthaven, Posterous, YC software).  The piece thus documents Gibson’s first VC role, its title, starting date, and the strategic context in which Initialized hired him.

mla_citation.page_title: “Welcome Alda and Brett. The Initialized team is leveling up with a new Partner & COO, and Operating Partner.”

pages.exhaustive_description: In the Fund V announcement (14 Aug 2020), Garry Tan names Gibson as a returning “General Partner” and highlights his domain expertise: “cloud, infrastructure, crypto, and AI/ML.”  The article confirms Gibson’s promotion path (Operating Partner → General Partner) and situates him on the six-person investment team overseeing a new $230 million seed fund.  It also reiterates that he joined the firm in 2017 and had grown into an all-round advisor, documenting both role and thematic focus at the General-Partner level.

mla_citation.page_title: “Announcing Initialized Fund V: Our team of honeybadgers is back with a $230M seed fund for startups pre-product market fit.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Business Insider’s news report on Garry Tan becoming CEO of Y Combinator (29 Aug 2022) contains the formal statement from Initialized that “Jen Wolf and Brett Gibson will take over as managing partners… Wolf will continue to lead operations, and Gibson will lead the firm’s investment strategy.”  This establishes the date (August 2022) and context of Gibson’s elevation to Managing Partner and clarifies his mandate within the partnership hierarchy.

mla_citation.page_title: “Y Combinator’s all-star alum and VC Garry Tan returns to take over the accelerator as its chief executive.”

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch’s 3 Oct 2024 article quotes and links to a memo by “the firm’s managing partner Brett Gibson” announcing a staff restructuring to “get back to basics.”  It shows Gibson acting in the top executive capacity—making firm-wide strategic and personnel decisions—and provides evidence of his continuing leadership as Managing Partner.  The piece also reiterates Initialized’s assets under management and portfolio highlights, situating Gibson’s role in the broader firm trajectory.

mla_citation.page_title: “Initialized Capital restructures, and lets multiple partners go.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Equilar’s ExecAtlas profile (snapshot dated 12 Feb 2025) gives an official bio supplied by Initialized Capital.  It lists Gibson’s current title (Managing Partner, Initialized Capital Management, LLC); notes board seats (CoinAlpha, Shogun); and, crucially, summarizes his investment domains—“crypto, dev tools, AI/ML, and cloud infrastructure.”  It also records his pre-VC software-founder history (Posthaven, Posterous, Slinkset, DrawHere) and thus corroborates the thematic focus of his venture practice.

mla_citation.page_title: “Brett Gibson – Executive Bio, Work History, and Contacts.”

pages.exhaustive_description: In this 7 Oct 2020 Q&A for the ‘Inquisitive VC’ series, Gibson (then a General Partner) narrates his transition from engineering to investing, detailing how he moved from advising on engineering in 2017 to “taking pitches on my own and advocating for deals.”  He elaborates on his investment interests—crypto, developer tooling, cloud infrastructure, AI/ML, robotics—and explains Initialized’s blind-vote, software-driven decision process.  The interview therefore provides primary-source insight into his investment philosophy, sector focus, and internal deal methodology.

mla_citation.page_title: “The Inquisitive VC: Brett Gibson — Initialized.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Forbes staff writer Alex Konrad reports on Initialized Capital’s very first Coinbase investment.  The article explains that Initialized (run at the time by Garry Tan, Alexis Ohanian and Harjeet Taggar) wrote “a combined seed-stage check of $300,000” in September 2012, split into three tranches ($50 K at a $9 M cap, another $50 K at a $12 M cap and $200 K in January 2013).  It notes that Coinbase’s direct listing on 14 Apr 2021 valued that early $300 K at roughly $680 million (a >2,200× return) and that Initialized later re-upped in the Series C (2015) and Series E (2018).  The piece provides color on how the deal was sourced while Tan was still a YC partner and states the exact $300 K amount, round (seed) and year (2012).

mla_citation.page_title: How Initialized Investor Garry Tan Turned a $300,000 Bet on Coinbase Into a $680 Million “Golden Ticket”

pages.exhaustive_description: The Coinbase Wikipedia entry’s IPO section confirms the outcome of Initialized’s seed bet.  It says Coinbase became a public company via direct listing on the Nasdaq on 14 April 2021, with a reference price of $250 a share and a first-day closing price of $328.28.  This page is used to document the investment’s exit (IPO on 14 Apr 2021).

mla_citation.page_title: Coinbase

pages.exhaustive_description: Crunchbase’s Instacart seed-round profile (announced 15 Oct 2012) lists a $2.3 million seed raise.  The investor table shows Initialized Capital (partner Garry Tan) alongside Khosla Ventures, FundersClub, Canaan, etc.  This provides year (2012), round (seed), amount ($2.3 M) and Initialized’s participation.

mla_citation.page_title: Seed Round – Instacart – 2012-10-15

pages.exhaustive_description: Instacart’s History section states: “In September 2023, the company became public through an initial public offering raising $660 million.”  This verifies the exit outcome (IPO, Sept 2023) for Initialized’s 2012 seed investment.

mla_citation.page_title: Instacart

pages.exhaustive_description: GM’s official 11 Mar 2016 press release announces that General Motors is acquiring Cruise Automation.  It confirms the exit (acquisition) and date (11 Mar 2016) of Initialized’s Cruise stake.

mla_citation.page_title: GM to Acquire Cruise Automation to Accelerate Autonomous Vehicle Development

pages.exhaustive_description: Employbl’s funding history page lists every Cruise round.  For the Series A on 17 Sep 2015 it shows “Initialized Capital” among the investors in a $12.5 million raise; for the March 2014 $4.3 million seed it again lists Initialized.  This establishes year (2014 seed, 2015 Series A), rounds, amounts and Initialized’s role.

mla_citation.page_title: Cruise Automation Funding & Investors

pages.exhaustive_description: Crunchbase records Rippling’s $7 million seed round (announced 14 Mar 2017).  Initialized Capital is listed as lead investor alongside Hydrazine Capital.  This supplies year (2017), round (seed), amount ($7 M) and Initialized’s role.

mla_citation.page_title: Seed Round – Rippling – 2017-03-14

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch’s May 9 2025 article reports Rippling’s $450 million Series G at a $16.8 billion valuation, bringing total funding to $1.85 billion.  It confirms that the company remains private and continues to raise large growth rounds (latest outcome as of 2025).

mla_citation.page_title: Rippling raises $450M at a $16.8B valuation, reveals YC is a customer

pages.exhaustive_description: Crunchbase shows Ro’s (then Roman) $3.1 million seed (7 Nov 2017) with Initialized Capital (partners Alexis Ohanian & Garry Tan) among the investors.  This provides year, round, amount and participation.

mla_citation.page_title: Seed Round – Ro – 2017-11-07

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch’s 26 Sep 2019 story on Mercury details a $20 million Series A led by CRV and notes that it follows “an investor-heavy $6 million seed round earlier this year” led by Andreessen Horowitz.  The piece discusses the bank-for-startups product, lists other investors and states post-money valuation ($100 M).  Initialized Capital is one of the nearly 40 seed investors (mentioned in the full investor list).  This gives year (2019), seed amount ($6 M), plus subsequent Series A.

mla_citation.page_title: Mercury banks $20M for its banking service aimed at startups

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch’s 26 Mar 2025 follow-up reports Mercury’s $300 million Series C led by Sequoia at a $3.5 billion valuation (more than double its 2021 valuation).  This establishes the latest outcome/fund-raise trajectory for the 2019 seed investment.

mla_citation.page_title: Fintech Mercury lands $300M in Sequoia-led Series C, doubles valuation to $3.5B

pages.exhaustive_description: Business Insider’s career profile on Brett Gibson opens with three personal-life bullet points, the first of which states that he “quit his job making pizza to teach himself how to code.” A following paragraph elaborates that after earning a B.A. in philosophy from the University of California, Santa Barbara, Gibson was “serving pizzas and trying to figure out what to do next,” before deciding to self-educate as a programmer. These details document his post-college food-service job (pizza maker/server) and the formative hobby of self-directed coding that preceded his tech career.

mla_citation.page_title: Brett Gibson went from making pizza to a rising-star crypto VC at Initialized Capital. Here’s how a chance encounter with Garry Tan changed the course of his career.

pages.exhaustive_description: Episode #32 of the “Waves in the Finoverse” podcast introduces Gibson as a “self-taught coder, philosopher, pizza maker, and pinball master before turning his hands to investments.” During the 24-minute interview (last updated 15 Mar 2023), host Walter Jennings and Gibson discuss: 1) Gibson’s earlier “career in pizza production,” which he likens to building startup “bases and toppings,” reaffirming pizza-making as a personal interest; 2) Jennings’ description of him as a “pinball master,” highlighting a long-standing hobby; and 3) the closing “Tracks in the Finoverse” segment where Gibson names Kendrick Lamar’s song “You” as the music that powers his personal journey—revealing a favorite musical artist.

mla_citation.page_title: Episode #32: Brett Gibson — Managing Partner at Initialized Capital

pages.exhaustive_description: The VC Sheet profile gives a concise biographical sketch and, under the main paragraph, notes a single personal-life detail: “He is fond of pinball.” This confirms pinball as a stated hobby independent of interviews and podcasts.

mla_citation.page_title: Brett Gibson (Initialized Capital) / VC Breakdown & Contact
mla_citation.author_name: VC Sheet staff (no individual author listed)

pages.exhaustive_description: The International Flipper Pinball Association (IFPA) player profile lists Brett Gibson (Player #66664) as a registered U.S. competitor, active for six years, with an open-rank of 9,655 and detailed rating/efficiency statistics. The listing verifies that he actively competes in organized pinball, substantiating the depth of the hobby referenced elsewhere.

mla_citation.page_title: Brett Gibson — IFPA Player Profile

pages.exhaustive_description: The Org’s public directory entry for Gibson states his current role at Initialized Capital and, under the “Location” heading, lists “San Francisco, United States.” This supplies the only reliable, published indication of his city of residence, a standard element of Wikipedia “Personal life” sections.

mla_citation.page_title: Brett Gibson – Managing Partner at Initialized Capital | The Org
